com.defano.jmonet.tools.selection

Interface TransformableCanvasSelection

  • All Superinterfaces:
    MutableSelection, Selection
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    LassoTool, SelectionTool

    public interface TransformableCanvasSelection
extends MutableSelection
    Represents a selection that can be transformed in a way that modifies the committed canvas image.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void eraseSelectedPixelsFromCanvas()
      Makes image bounded by the selection frame appear to have been deleted by filling the selection frame with paint in the remove-scratch buffer.
      default void pickupSelection()
      Add the graphics underneath the selection to the currently selected image.

      • Methods inherited from interface com.defano.jmonet.tools.selection.MutableSelection

        resetSelection, setDirty, setSelectedImage, setSelectionOutline, translateSelection

      • Methods inherited from interface com.defano.jmonet.tools.selection.Selection

        crop, getCanvas, getIdentitySelectionFrame, getSelectedImage, getSelectionFrame, getSelectionLocation, hasSelection, redrawSelection

    • Method Detail

      • eraseSelectedPixelsFromCanvas

        void eraseSelectedPixelsFromCanvas()
        Makes image bounded by the selection frame appear to have been deleted by filling the selection frame with paint in the remove-scratch buffer.

        This method does not mark the selection as dirty, nor does it commit this change to the canvas. Callers are expected to invoke MutableSelection.setDirty() or commit the scratch buffer to the canvas if this change is intended to be permanent.

      • pickupSelection

        default void pickupSelection()
        Add the graphics underneath the selection to the currently selected image. Has no effect if a selection is not active or has not been dirtied.

        This method "picks up" the paint underneath the selection (that wasn't part of the paint initially picked up when the selection bounds were defined).
